sentence.value: William "Bill" Barton Bridgeman (1916 – September 29, 1968) was an American test pilot who broke aviation records while working for the Douglas aircraft company testing experimental aircraft.

sentence.value: In July 1951, the United States Navy announced that the Douglas Skyrocket (D-558-II) piloted by Bridgeman had "attained the highest speed and altitude ever recorded by a piloted plane."

sentence.value: On August 15 of the same year, he set a world record with a speed of Mach 1.88 and an unofficial record height of 79,494 feet (24,230 m).

sentence.value: He graduated and was commissioned in 1941, and was sent to Pearl Harbor, where he experienced the Japanese attack on December 7.
sentence.annotated-sentence: He graduated and was commissioned in [[1941|1941]], and was sent to [[Pearl Harbor|Pearl_Harbor]], where he experienced [[the Japanese attack|Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor]] on [[December 7|December_7]].

sentence.value: He flew PBY Catalina flying boats in the New Guinea/Australia sector, then four-engined PB4Y-2 Privateer patrol bombers on a tour of operations with VP/VPB-109 Squadron (the "Reluctant Raiders").

sentence.value: He was reassigned afterwards to training activities stateside from August 1944 until the end of the war, then spent two years flying transport missions from Pearl Harbor to the West Coast.

sentence.value: Upon leaving the Navy in 1947, Bridgeman joined Southwest Airlines (a local West Coast airline that eventually merged into Pacific Southwest Airlines, not to be confused with today's Southwest) to fly DC-3s on the San Francisco-Seattle route.

sentence.value: Bored with the airline routine, he left in 1949 to join the Douglas Aircraft Company as a production test pilot to certify A-1 Skyraiders off the assembly line before their delivery to the Navy.

sentence.value: Bridgeman converted to jet aircraft on the F-80 in early 1950 and eventually conducted a very successful test program with the Skyrocket, collecting data on the behavior of swept-wing aircraft over a wide envelope of load factors and Mach numbers deep in the supersonic range.

sentence.value: In May 1951, he broke the world speed record with Mach 1.72, then raised the record to Mach 1.88 (1,245 mph, 1,992 km/h) the next month.

sentence.value: Immediately afterwards, he broke the world altitude record with 79,494 ft. (24,230 m) on the Skyrocket's final flight before delivery to NACA.

sentence.value: During this campaign, Bridgeman was one of the first pilots to encounter the phenomenon of inertia coupling, a flight hazard that would dominate high-speed aircraft research for much of the 1950s.

sentence.value: In 1955, he recounted his experiences test-flying the Skyraider and Skyrocket in a successful memoir, The Lonely Sky, written with Jacqueline Hazard, whom he married shortly after the book was published.

sentence.value: He was an astronaut candidate for the United States Air Force Man In Space Soonest program, but the program was cancelled on August 1, 1958, and replaced by NASA's Project Mercury.

sentence.value: Bridgeman eventually moved to Grumman Aircraft where he conducted test programs of commercial aircraft, then pursued a career in commercial real estate.
sentence.annotated-sentence: Bridgeman eventually moved to [[Grumman Aircraft|Grumman]] where he conducted test programs of [[commercial aircraft|Commercial_property]], then pursued [[a career|Career]] in [[commercial real estate|Commercial_property]].

sentence.value: In September 1968, his airplane went down in the Pacific Ocean during a routine leisure flight from Los Angeles to Santa Catalina Island.
sentence.annotated-sentence: In [[September|September_(Daughtry_song)]] [[1968|An_American_Carol]], [[his airplane|Airplane]] went down in [[the Pacific Ocean|Pacific_Ocean]] during a routine [[leisure|Leisure]] [[flight|Flight]] from [[Los Angeles|Los_Angeles]] to [[Santa Catalina Island|Santa_Catalina_Island,_California]].
